Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: What am I, Mr. Lambert?

Speaker: lambert
Dialogue: Bitten, Mr. Fennyman.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: How badly bitten, Mr. Frees?

Speaker: frees
Dialogue: Twelve pounds, one shilling and four pence, Mr. Fennyman, including interest.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Aaagh! I can pay you!

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: When?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Two weeks, three at the most, Aaaagh! For pity's sake.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Take his feet out. Where will you get

Speaker: frees
Dialogue: Sixteen pounds, five shillings and nine pence

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: including interest in three weeks?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: I have a wonderful new play!

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Put his feet in.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: It's a comedy.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Cut his nose off.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: A new comedy. By Will Shakespeare!

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: And his ears.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: And a share. We will be partners, Mr. Fennyman!

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Partners!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: It's a crowd-tickler--mistaken identities, a shipwreck, a pirate king, a bit with a dog, and love triumphant.

Speaker: lambert
Dialogue: I think I've seen it. I didn't like it.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: This time it is by Shakespeare.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: What's the title?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Romeo and Ethel the Pirate's Daughter.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Good title.

Speaker: frees
Dialogue: Twenty pounds to the penny, Mr. Fennyman.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Correct!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: But I have to pay the actors and the authors.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: A share of the profits.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: There's never any

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Of course not!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Mr. Fennyman, I think you may have hit on something.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Sign here.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Without doubt he is completing it at this very moment.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Will! Where is my play? Tell me you have it nearly done! Tell me you have it started.  You have begun?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Doubt that the stars are fire, doubt that the sun doth move

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: No, no, we haven't the time. Talk prose. Where is my play?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: It is all locked safe in here

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: God be praised!  Locked?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: As soon as I have found my muse

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Who is she this time?!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: She is always Aphrodite.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Aphrodite Baggot who does it behind the Dog and Trumpet?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Henslowe, you have no soul so how can you understand the emptiness that seeks a soulmate?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Well, I am a dead man and buggered to boot. My theatre is close by the plague these twelve weeks, my company is playing the inn-yards of England, while Burbage and the Chamberlain's Men are invited to court and receive ten pounds to play your piece, written for my theatre, by my writer, at my risk when you were green and grateful -

Speaker: will
Dialogue: What piece? Richard Crookback?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: No--it's comedy they want, Will! Comedy! Like Romeo and Ethel?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Who wrote that?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Nobody! You are writing it for me! I gave you three pounds a month since.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Half what you owed me. I am still due for One Gentleman of Verona.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: . . . Will! What is money to you and me? I, your patron, you my wordwright! When the plague lifts Burbage will have a new Christopher Marlowe for the Curtain and I have nothing for the Rose.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Mr. Henslowe, will you lend me fifty pounds?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Fifty pounds? What for?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Burbage offers me a partnership in the Chamberlain's Men. For fifty pounds my hired player days are over.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Cut out my heart! Throw my liver to the dogs!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: No, then.

Speaker: makepeace
Dialogue: and the Lord shall smite them! Yea, harken to me. The theatres are handmaidens of the devil! Under the name of the Curtain, the players breed lewdness in your wives, rebellion in your servants, idleness in your apprentices and wickedness in your children! And the Rose smells thusly rank by any name! I say a plague on both their houses!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: To my weekly confession.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Words, words, wordsonce, I had the giftI could make love out of words as a potter makes cups out of clay love that overthrows empires, love that binds two hearts together come hellfire and brimstonesfor sixpence a line, I could cause a riot in a nunnerybut now

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Aye, now and again, but what of it? I have lost my gift.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I have lost my gift.  It's as if my quill is broken. As if the organ of the imagination has dried up. As if the proud tower of my genius has collapsed.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Nothing comes.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: It is like trying to a pick a lock with a wet herring.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: A goodly length in times past, but lately

Speaker: later
Dialogue: Not much sand left.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I was a lad of eighteen. Anne Hathaway was a woman, half as old again.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: She had a cottage. One day, she was three months gone with child, so

Speaker: will
Dialogue: On my mother's side the Ardens

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Four years and a hundred miles away in Stratford. A cold bed too, since the twins were born. Banishment was a blessing.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: yet cannot love nor write it.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Will it restore my gift?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Now where? Will?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: To the Palace at Whitehall.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Prithee, Mr. Kempe, break a leg. You too, good Crab.

Speaker: kempe
Dialogue: Crab is nervous. He has never played the Palace. When will you write me a tragedy, Will? I could do it.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: No, they would laugh at Seneca if you played it.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: My sleeve wants for a button, Mistress Rosaline, where were my seamstress's eyes?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I am still owed money for this play, Burbage.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: Not from me. I only stole it. When are you coming over to the Chamberlain's Men?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: When I have fifty pounds.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: Are you writing?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: A comedy. All but done, a pirate comedy, wonderful.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: What is the chief part?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Romeo. Wit, swordsman, lover.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: The title?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Romeo

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: I will play him. Bring it tomorrow.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: It's for Henslowe. He paid me.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: How much?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Ten pounds.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: You're a liar.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I swear it. He wants Romeo for Ned and the Admiral's Men.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: Ned is wrong for it.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Done.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Burbage, I will see you hanged for a pickpocket.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: The Queen has commanded, she loves a comedy and the Master of the Revels favours us.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: And what favour does Mr. Tilney receive from you?

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: Ask him.

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: She comes!

Speaker: rosaline
Dialogue: When will you write me a sonnet, Will?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I have lost my gift.

Speaker: rosaline
Dialogue: You left it in my bed. Come to look for it again.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Are you to be my muse, ROSALINE?

Speaker: rosaline
Dialogue: Burbage has my keeping but you have my heart.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You see? The consumptives plot against me. "Will Shakespeare has a play, let us go and cough through it."

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I feel a scene coming on.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Is it about a pirate's daughter?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: You see? Comedy.

Speaker: queen
Dialogue: Well played, Master Crab, I commend you.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Love and a bit with a dog, that's what they like.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: There's a lady knows your play by heart.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Did you like Proteus or Valentine best? Proteus for speaking, Valentine for looks.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: I liked the dog, for laughs.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: But Silvia I did not care for much. His fingers were red from fighting and he spoke like a schoolboy at lessons. Stage love will never be true love while the law of the land has our heroines played by pipsqueak boys in petticoats! Oh, when can we see another?

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: When the Queen commands it.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: But at the playhouse. Nurse?

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Be still.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: I am not so well-born.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Well-monied is the same as well-born and well-married is more so. Lord Wessex was looking at you tonight.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: All the men at court are without poetry. If they look at me they see my father's fortune. I will have poetry in my life. And adventure. And love. Love above all.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Like Valentine and Silvia?

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: No . . . not the artful postures of love, but love that over- throws life. Unbiddable, ungovernable, like a riot in the heart, and nothing to be done, come ruin or rapture. Love like there has never been in a play.  I will have love or I will end my days as a . . .

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: As a nurse.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: But I would be Valentine and Silvia too. Good Nurse, God save you and good night. I would stay asleep my whole life if I could dream myself into a company of players.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Clean your teeth while you dream, then.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: This time we take your boots off!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: What have I done, Mr. Fennyman?

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: The theatres are all closed by the plague!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Oh, that.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: by order of the Master of the Revels!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Mr. Fennyman, let me explain about the theatre business.  The natural condition is one of insurmountable obstacles on the road to imminent disaster. Believe me, to be close by the plague is a bagatelle in the ups and downs of owning a theatre.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: So what do we do?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Nothing. Strangely enough , it all turns out well.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: I don't know. It's a mystery.

Speaker: lambert
Dialogue: Should I kill him, Mr. Fennyman?

Speaker: messenger
Dialogue: The theatres are reopened. By order of the Master of the Revels, the theatres are reopened

Speaker: frees
Dialogue: Mr. Fennyman! Mr. Tilney has opened the playhouses.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Yes I heard.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: If you wouldn't mind

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Where is the play?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Oh, it's coming, it's coming.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Will! The theatres are

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Romeo and Rosaline. Scene One! God, I'm good!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Rosaline? You mean Ethel.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Richard!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Burbage?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Mr. Tilney

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: Like you, I found him not at home!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: So this is the favour you find in the Chamberlain's Men.

Speaker: rosaline
Dialogue: Will!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Tell Burbage he has lost a new play by Will Shakespeare.

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: What does Burbage care of that? He is readying the Curtain for Kit Marlowe.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You have opened the playhouses?

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: I have, Master Shakespeare.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: But the plague

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: Yes, I know. But he was always hanging around the house.

Speaker: rosaline
Dialogue: Willyou're the only one, Will!--in my heart.

Speaker: nol
Dialogue: Mr. Henslowe!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Yes, I heard. The theatres are open. But where is my playwright?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Chalk it up, Nol. I'm hungry, too.

Speaker: nol
Dialogue: The special today is a pig's foot marinated in juniper-berry vinegar, served with a buckwheat pancake which has been

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Will! Have you finished?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Yes. Nearly.  It's all locked safe in here. We need Ralph for the Pirate King. Good morning, Master Nol. You will have a nice little part.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Ned Alleyn and the Admiral's Men are out on tour. I need actors. Those here who are unknown will have a chance to be known.

Speaker: actor
Dialogue: What about the money, Mr. Henslowe?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: It won't cost you a penny! Auditions in half-an-hour!

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Never when I'm working.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Give me to drink mandragora.

Speaker: barman
Dialogue: Straight up, Will?

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Give my friend a beaker of your best brandy.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Kit

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: How goes it, Will?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Wonderful, wonderful.

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: Burbage says you have a play.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I have. And chinks to show for it.

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: Not new--my Doctor Faustus.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I love your early work. "Was this the face that launched a thousand ships and burnt the topless towers of Ilium?"

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: I have a new one nearly done, and better. The Massacre at Paris.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Good title.

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: And yours?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Romeo and Ethel the Pirate's Daughter.  Yes, I know.

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: What is the story?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Well, there's a pirate  In truth, I have not written a word.

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: Romeo isItalian. Always in and out of love.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Yes, that's good. Until he meets

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: Ethel.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Do you think?

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: The daughter of his enemy.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: The daughter of his enemy.

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: His best friend is killed in a duel by Ethel's brother or something. His name is Mercutio.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Mercutiogood name.

Speaker: nol
Dialogue: Will--they're waiting for you!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I'm coming.

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: I thought your play was for Burbage.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: This is a different one.

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: A different one you haven't written?

Speaker: young actor
Dialogue: " Was this the face that launched a thousand ships, And burnt the topless towers of Ilium? Sweet Helen, make me immortal with a kiss!"

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: second actor
Dialogue: I would like to give you something from Faustus by Christopher Marlowe.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: How refreshing.

Speaker: second actor
Dialogue: "Was this the face that launched a thousand ships, And burnt the topless towers of Ilium?"

Speaker: urchin
Dialogue: "the topless towers of Ilium? Sweet Helen, make me immortal with a--?"

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Thank you!

Speaker: wabash
Dialogue: "W-w-w-w-was th-th-this th-th-the f-f- f-face"

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Very good, Mr. Wabash. Excellent. Report to the property master.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I did not.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Well, I to my work, you to yours. When can I see pages?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Tomorrow

Speaker: actor
Dialogue: May I begin, sir?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Your name?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Take off your hat.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Where did you learn how to do that?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Wait there.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Let me see you. Take off your hat.

Speaker: actor
Dialogue: What are we playing?

Speaker: nol
Dialogue: Where are the pages?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Where's the boy?

Speaker: wabash
Dialogue: B-b-b-b-break a l-l-l-leg!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Follow that boat!

Speaker: boatman
Dialogue: Right you are, governor!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: boatman
Dialogue: Yes, I've seen you in something. That one about a king.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: boatman
Dialogue: I had the Christopher Marlowe in my boat once.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Do you know that house?

Speaker: boatman
Dialogue: Sir Robert De Lesseps.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: God save you, mother.  Ho water, nurse.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Who asks for him?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: William Shakespeare, actor, poet, and playwright of the Rose.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Master Kent ismy nephew.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I will wait.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Much god may it do you.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: He sees himself in me! Romeo Montague, a young man of Verona.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Verona again.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: A comedy of quarreling families reconciled in the discovery of Romeo to be the very same Capulet cousin stolen from the cradle and fostered to manhood by his Montague mother that was robbed of her own child by the Pirate King!

Speaker: servant
Dialogue: Be off!

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Your mother, and your father

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: From tomorrow, away in the country for three weeks! Is Master Shakespeare not handsome?

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: He looks well enough for a mountebank.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Oh, Nurse! He would give Thomas Kent the life of Viola De Lesseps's dreaming.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: My lady, this play will end badly. I will tell.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: You will not tell. As you love me and as I love you, you will bind my breast and buy me a boy's wig!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Master Plum! What business here?

Speaker: musician
Dialogue: A five shilling business, Will. We play for the dancing.

Speaker: servant
Dialogue: Musicians don't eat, Sir Robert's orders.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I seek Master Thomas Kent.

Speaker: sir robert
Dialogue: She is a beauty, my lord, as would take a king to church for a dowry of a nutmeg.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: My plantations in Virginia are not mortgaged for a nutmeg. I have an ancient name that will bring you preferment when your grandson is a Wessex. Is she fertile?

Speaker: sir robert
Dialogue: She will breed. If she do not, send her back.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Is she obedient?

Speaker: sir robert
Dialogue: As any mule in Christendom. But if you are the man to rider her, their are rubies in the saddlebag.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: I like her.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: By all the stars in heaven, who is she?

Speaker: musician
Dialogue: Viola de Lesseps. Dream on, Will.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Master Shakespeare

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: My lady Viola.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: My lord.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: I have spoken with your father.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: So my lord? I speak with him every day.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: "Poet?"

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I was a poet till now, but I have seen beauty that puts my poems at one with the talking ravens at the Tower.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: By coveting my property. I cannot shed blood in her house but I will cut your throat anon. You have a name?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Christopher Marlowe at your service.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Romeo, Romeo . . . a young man of Verona. A comedy. By William Shakespeare.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: My lady!

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Who is there?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Will Shakespeare!

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Anon, good nurse. Anon.  Master Shakespeare?!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: The same, alas.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Oh but why "alas?"

Speaker: will
Dialogue: A lowly player.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Alas indeed, for I thought you the highest poet of my esteem and a writer of plays that capture my heart.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Oh--I am him too!

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: I will come again.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Oh, I am fortune's fool, I will be punished for this!

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: If they find you here they will kill you.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You can bring them with a word.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Oh, not for the world!

Speaker: john
Dialogue: "Draw if you be men!  Gregory, remember thy washing blow."

Speaker: nol
Dialogue: "Part, fools, put up your swords."

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: It starts well, and then it's all long- faced about some Rosaline. Where's the comedy, Will. Where's the dog?  Do you think it is funny?

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: I was a Pirate King, now I'm a Nurse. That's funny

Speaker: will
Dialogue: We are at least six men short, and those we have will be overparted, ranters and stutterers who should be sent back to the stews. My Romeo has let me down. I see disaster.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: We are at least four acts short, Will, if you are looking for disaster.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Who are you, master?

Speaker: urchin
Dialogue: I am Ethel, sir, the Pirate's daughter.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I'll be damned if you are!

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Is it going well?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Very well.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: But nothing is happening.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Yes, but very well.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Gentlemen! Thank you! You are welcome.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Who is that?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Nobody. The author.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: We are about to embark on a great voyage.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: It is customary to make a little speech on the first day. It does no harm and authors like it.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You want to know what parts you are to receive. All will be settled as we go

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: Huzzah! The Admiral's Men are returned to the house!

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Who is this?

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: Silence, you god! I am Hieronimo! I am Tamburlaine! I am Faustus! I am Barrabas, the Jew of Malta--of yes, Master Will, and I am Henry VI. What is the play, and what is my part?

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: A moment, sir!

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: I am the money!

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: Then you may remain so long as you remain silent. Pay attention and you will see how genius creates a legend.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Thank you, sir.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: We are in desperate want of a Mercutio, Ned, a young nobleman of Verona

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: And the title of this piece?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Mercutio

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Is it?

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: I will play him!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Mr. Pope! Mr. Phillips! Welcome, George Bryan! James Armitage!  Sam! My pretty one! Are you ready to fall in love again?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I am, Master Shakespeare.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Have they dropped?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: No, no, a touch of cold only. We suspect he is lying but WILL has turned away.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Master Henslowe, you have your actors.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: I saw his Tamburlaine, you know. Wonderful.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Yes, I saw it.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Of course, it was mighty writing. There is no one like Marlowe

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Better fortune, boy.

Speaker: urchin
Dialogue: I was in a play. They cut my head off in Titus Andronicus. When I write plays, they will be like Titus.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You admire it?

Speaker: urchin
Dialogue: I like it when they cut heads off. And the daughter mutilated with knives.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Oh. What is your name?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I have to get back.

Speaker: montague
Dialogue: "I would thou wert so happy by thy stay To hear true shrift. Come, madam, let's away."

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Cut round him for now.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: What? Who?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Romeo.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: The one who came with your letter?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Good

Speaker: will
Dialogue: No, no, noDon't spend it all at once!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Do you understand me?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: He is speaking about a baggage we never even meet! What will be left in your purse when he meets his Juliet?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Juliet? You mean Ethel.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: What will you do in Act Two when he meets the love of his life?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Of course you have not! I have not written it!

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: WillWhere is Mercutio?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Locked safe in here. I leave the scene in your safe keeping, Ned, I have a sonnet to write.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: A sonnet? You mean a play.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Two hours at prayer!

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Lady Viola is pious, my lord.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Piety is for Sunday! And two hours at prayer is not piety, it is self- importance!

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: It would be better that you return tomorrow, my lord.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: It would be better that you tell her to get off her knees and show some civility to her six-day lord and master.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Lord Wessex. You have been waiting.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: I am aware of it, but it is beauty's privilege.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: You flatter, my lord.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: No. I have spoken to the Queen.  Her majesty's consent is requisite when a Wessex takes a wife, and once gained, her consent is her command.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Do you intend to marry, my lord?

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Your father should keep you better informed. He has bought me for you. He returns from his estates to see us married two weeks from Saturday.  You are allowed to show your pleasure.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: I do not love you, my lord.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: How your mind hops about! Your father was a shopkeeper, your children will bear arms, and I will recover my fortune. That is the only matter under discussion today. You will like Virginia.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Virginia?!

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Why, yes! My fortune lies in my plantations. The tobacco weed. I need four thousand pounds to fit out a ship and put my investments to work--I fancy tobacco has a future. We will not stay there long, three or four years . . .

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: But why me?

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: It was your eyes. No, your lips.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: The Queen has consented?

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: She wants to inspect you. At Greenwich, come Sunday. Be submissive, modest, grateful and brief.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: I will do my duty, my lord.

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: Gentlemen upstage, ladies downstage!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You did not like the speech?

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: The speech is excellent.  "Oh, then I see Queen Mab hath been with you!" Excellent and a good length. But then he disappears for the length of a bible.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: There you have his duel, a skirmish of words and swords such as I never wrote, nor anyone. He dies with such passion and poetry as your ever heard: "a plague on both your houses!"

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: He dies?

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: Will!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Did you give her my letter?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Oh, Thomas! She has cut my strings! I am unmanned, unmended, and unmade, like a puppet in a box.

Speaker: boatman
Dialogue: Writer, is he?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Row your boat.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: She tells me to keep away. She is to marry Lord Wessex. What should I do?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: And break her heart and mine?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: She loves me, Thomas!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: No. And yet she does where the ink has run with tears. Was she weeping when she gave you this?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Your aunt?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Like a sickness and its cure together.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Oh, if I could write the beauty of her eyes! I was born to look in them and know myself.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Oh, Thomas, her lips! The early morning rose would wither on the branch, if it could feel envy!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Deeper. Softer. None of your twittering larks! I would banish nightingales from her garden before they interrupt her song.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Constantly. Without doubt. And plays the lute, she has a natural ear. And her bosom--did I mention her bosom?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Oh Thomas, a pair of pippins! As round and rare as golden apples!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Yes, by God! Love knows nothing of rank or riverbank! It will spark between a queen and the poor vagabond who plays the king, and their love should be minded by each, for love denied blights the soul we owe to God! So tell my lady, William Shakespeare waits for her in the garden!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: For one kiss, I would defy a thousand Wessexes!

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Oh, Will!

Speaker: boatman
Dialogue: Thank you, my lady!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Lady?

Speaker: boatman
Dialogue: Viola De Lesseps. Known her since she was this high. Wouldn't deceive a child.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Can you love a fool?

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Can you love a player?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Wait! You are still a maid and perhaps as mistook in me as I was mistook in Thomas Kent.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Answer me only this: are you the author of the plays of William Shakespeare?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Then kiss me again for I am not mistook.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: It is strange to me, too.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Go to, go to.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: I would not have thought it. There is something better than a play.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: There is.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Even your play.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Oh

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: And that was only my first try.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Well perhaps better than my first.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Will

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I must. Look-- how pale the window.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Moonlight!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: No, the morning rooster woke me.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: It was the owl--come to bed

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Oh, let Henslowe wait.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Mr. Henslowe?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Let him be damned for his pages!

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Oh--no, no!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: There is time. It is still dark.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: It is broad day!  The rooster tells us so!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: It was the owl. Believe me, love, it was the owl.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: You would leave us players without a scene to read today?!

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: My lady, the house is stirring, it is a new day.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: It is a new world!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: It's you.

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: Suffering cats!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Yesyesernot quite rightit is more let me  "Then have my lips the sin that they have took."

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: Well! It was lucky you were here! Why do not I write the rest of your play while you

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Yes, yescontinue. Now the Nurse. Where is Ralph?

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Oh let it be night!

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Oh, do not go

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I must. I must

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: "Arise fair sun and kill the envious moon Who is already sick and pale with grief That thou her maid art far more fair than she"

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Yes, some of it is speakable.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: "It is my lady, O it is my love! O that she knew she were!"

Speaker: will
Dialogue: "Oh Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thou Romeo? Deny thy father and refuse thy name."

Speaker: will
Dialogue: "What man art thou that thus bescreen'd in night So stumblest on my counsel?"

Speaker: will
Dialogue: "The orchard walls are high and hard to climb, And the place death, considering who thou art, If any of my kinsmen find thee here. If they do see thee, they will murder thee."

Speaker: will
Dialogue: "Good night, good night. As sweet repose and rest Come to thy heart as that within my breast. O wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?"

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: That's my line!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Oh, but it is mine too!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: "My bounty is as boundless as the sea, My love as deep:

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Anon, good Nurse

Speaker: will
Dialogue: "Stay but a little, I will come again."

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: "I am feared,

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Oh, she's off again! She says she's going and then she doesn't

Speaker: will
Dialogue: How is it?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: It's all right.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: NedI knowI know

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: It's good.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Oh

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: The title won't do.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Ah

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: Romeo and Juliet--just a suggestion.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Thank you, Ned.

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: And you are a Warwickshire shit-house.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: You mean, no dog of any kind?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: The Friar married them in secret, then Ned gets into a fight with one of the Capulets, Romeo tries to stop them, he gets in Ned's way, I mean in Mercutio's way, so Tybalt kills Mercutio and then Romeo kills Tybalt. Then the Prince banishes him from Verona.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: That must be when he goes on the voyage and gets shipwrecked on the island of the Pirate King.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Cease your prattling! Get out!  A thousand apologies!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Sundayit is Sunday.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Oh, but it will end well for love?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: In heaven, perhaps. It is not a comedy I am writing now. A broad river divides my lovers--family, duty, fate--as unchangeable as nature.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Yes, this is not life, Will. This is a stolen season.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Sunday! Greenwich!

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Now, pay attention, Nursy. The Queen, Gloriana Regina, God's Chosen Vessel, the Radiant One, who shines her light on us, is at Greenwich today, and prepared, during the evening's festivities, to bestow her gracious favour on my choice of wife--and if we're late for lunch, the old boot will not forgive. So you get you to my lady's chamber and produce her with or without her undergarments.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You cannot! Not for the Queen herself!

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: What will you have me do? Marry you instead?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: To be the wife of a poor player?--can I wish that for Lady Viola, except in my dreams? And yet I would, if I were free to follow my desire in the harsh light of day.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: You follow your desire freely enough in the night. So, if that is all, to Greenwich I go.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Then I will go with you.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: You cannot, Wessex will kill you

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I know how to fight!

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Oh, Will! As Thomas Kent my heart belongs to you but as Viola the river divides us, and I will marry Wessex a week from Saturday.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: By heaven, I will drag her down, by the Queen's command

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Good morning, my lord!

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Ah! My lady! The tide waits for no man, but I swear it would wait for you!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Here we come at last, my lord!

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Are you bringing your laundry woman?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Her chaperone. My lady's country cousin.  My, but you be a handsome gallant, just as she said! You may call me Miss Wilhelmina!

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: On a more fortuitous occasion, perhaps

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Oh, my lord, you will not shake me off, she never needed me more, I sear by your breeches!

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Now?

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: The Queen asks for you. Answer well.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: A man, my lord?

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: There was a man, poet--a theatre poet, I heard--does he come to the house?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: A theatre poet?

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: An insolent penny-a-page rogue, Marlowe, he said, Christopher Marlowe--has he been to the house?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Marlowe? Oh yes, he is the one, lovely waistcoat, shame about the poetry.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: That dog!

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Your Majesty.

Speaker: queen
Dialogue: Stand up straight, girl.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Your Majesty.

Speaker: queen
Dialogue: What do you love so much?

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Your Majesty

Speaker: queen
Dialogue: Speak out! I know who I am. Do you love stories of kings and queens? Feats of arms? Or is it courtly love?

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: I love theatre. To have stories acted for me by a company of fellows is indeed

Speaker: queen
Dialogue: They are not acted for you, they are acted for me.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: And I love poetry above all.

Speaker: queen
Dialogue: Above Lord Wessex?

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Oh, but they can!

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Lady Viola isyoung in the world. Your Majesty is wise in it. Nature and truth are the very enemies of playacting. I'll wager my fortune.

Speaker: queen
Dialogue: I thought you were here because you had none.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Fifty pounds!

Speaker: queen
Dialogue: Fifty pounds! A very worthy sum on a very worthy question. Can a play show us the very truth and nature of love? I bear witness to the wager, and will be the judge of it as occasion arises.  Have her then, but you are a lordly fool. She has been plucked since I saw her last, and not by you. It takes a woman to know it.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Marlowe!

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: Burbage!

Speaker: burbage's voice
Dialogue: Who's there?

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: Marlowe.

Speaker: burbage's voice
Dialogue: Kit!

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: You are playing my Faustus this afternoon. Don't spend yourself in sport.

Speaker: rosaline
Dialogue: This afternoon!--we'll still be here this afternoon.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: What do you want, Kit?

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: My Massacre at Paris is complete.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: You have the last act?

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: You have the money?

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: Tomorrow.

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: Then tomorrow you will have the pages.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: Wait!  Will you desist!

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: Twenty pounds on delivery

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: What is money to me like us? Besides, if I need a play, I have another waiting, a comedy by Shakespeare.

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: Romeo?--he gave it to Henslowe.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: Never!

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: Well, I am to Deptford now, I leave my respects, Miss Rosaline.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: I gave Shakespeare two sovereigns for Romeo!

Speaker: marlowe
Dialogue: You did. But Ned Alleyn and the Admiral's Men have the playing of it as the Rose.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: Treachery!

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: Are you going to do it like that? And before the humbled actor can reply NED continues.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: Where is that thieving hack who can't keep his pen in his own ink pot!?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: What is this rabble?!

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Wonderful, wonderful! And a dog!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Not with my props!

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Will! What--?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: A literary feud. Quite normal.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I dreamed last night of a shipwreck. You were cast ashore in a far country.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: We need that for the balcony scene!

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: My investment! LAMBERT!!!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: I want no more trouble, Mr. Fennyman. As I explained to you, the theatre business

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Henslowe, you pound of tripe, in my business I would be out of business if I had your courage, so don't tell me about business

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Poxy Pol! You keep yourself to yourself I'll not have you infecting my investment!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: It is also a tavern.

Speaker: pretty whore
Dialogue: I remember you! The poet!

Speaker: second whore
Dialogue: Oh, he's a pretty one! Tell me your story while I tickle your fancy!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: It is, Thomas, but of good reputation. Come, there is no harm in a drink.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Never when I'm working!

Speaker: pretty whore
Dialogue: Never tried it? Never?  I think you are ready, Sam!

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: You are welcome to my best house! Here's to the Admiral's Men!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Iquite liked it.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Master Kent! You have not dipped your wick?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Mr. Fennyman, because you love the theatre you must have a part in my play. I am writing an Apothecary, a small but vital role.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: By heaven, I thank you! I will be your Apothecary!

Speaker: whore
Dialogue: And what is this play about?

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Well, there's this Nurse

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Mr. Shakespeare has given me the part of the Apothecary!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: The Apothecary? Will, what is the story? Where is the shipwreck? How does the comedy end?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: By God, I wish I knew.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: By God, Will, if you do not, who does? Let us have pirates, clowns, and a happy ending, or we will send you back to Stratford to your wife!

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Will! Mr. Henslowe! Gentlemen all!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Ohwhat have I done?

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: He was the first man among us. A great light has gone out.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: It was I who killed him! God forgive me, God forgive me!

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: You look sad, my lady! Let me take you riding.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: It is not my riding day, my lord.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Bless me, I thought it was a horse.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: I am going to church.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: I understand of course. It is to be expected.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: It is to be expected on a Sunday.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: And on a day of mourning. I never met the fellow but once at your house.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Mourning? Who is dead, my lord?

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Oh!--dear God, I did not think it would be me to tell you. A great loss to playwriting, and to dancing.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: He is dead?

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Killed last night, in a tavern! Come, then, we'll say a prayer for his soul

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: My ladymy ladynow is the time to show your breeding.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Oh, spare me, dear ghost, spare me for the love of Christ!

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Will!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: It is worse. I have killed a man.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Marlowe's touch was in my Titus Andronicus and my Henry VI was a house built on his foundations.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: You never spoke so well of him.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: He was not dead before. I would exchange all my plays to come for all of his that will never come.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: You lie.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: My love is no lie. I have a wife, yes, and I cannot marry the daughter of Sir Robert de Lesseps. It needed no wife come from Stratford to tell you that. And yet you let me come to your bed.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Calf love. I loved the writer, and gave up the prize for a sonnet.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I was the more deceived.

Speaker: voila
Dialogue: Yes--you were deceived. For I never loved you till now.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Now?

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: I love you, Will, beyond poetry.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Oh, my love  You ran from me before.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: You were not dead before. When I thought you dead, I did not care about all the plays that will never come, only that I would never see your face. I saw our end, and it will come.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You cannot marry Wessex!

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: If not Wessex the Queen will know the cause and there will be no more Will Shakespeare.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Nono.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: But I will go to Wessex as a widow from these vows, as solemn as they are unsanctified.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: For killing Juliet's kinsman Tybalt, the one who killed Romeo's friend Mercutio, Romeo is banished

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You, Edward. The Friar who married them gives Juliet a potion to drink. It is a secret potion. It makes her seeming dead. She is placed in the tomb of the Capulets. She will awake to life and love when Romeo comes to her side again.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: That's me.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: And buys a deadly poison. He enters the tomb to say farewell to Juliet who lies there cold as death. He drinks the poison. He dies by her side. And then she wakes and sees him dead.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Well, that will have them rolling in the aisles.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Sad and wonderful! I have a blue velvet cap which will do well, I have seen apothecary with a cap just so.

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: Yes--it will serve. But there's a scene missing between marriage and death.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: The play. All written out for you. I had the clerk at Bridewell do it, he has a good fist for lettering.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Will you read it for me?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: "Wilt thou be gone? It is not yet near day> It was the nightingale and not the lark That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear. Nightly she sings on yon pomegranate tree. Believe me, love, it was the nightingale."

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: "It was the lark, the herald of the morn, No nightingale. Look, love, what envious streaks Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east. Night's candles are burnt out, and jocund day Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops. I must be gone and live, or stay and die."

Speaker: will
Dialogue: "Yon light is not daylight, I know it, I. It is some meteor that the sun exhales To be to thee this night a torchbearer"

Speaker: will
Dialogue: "thou need'st not to be gone."

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: "I have more care to stay than will to go. Come death, and welcome. Juliet wills it so. How is't my soul? Let's talk. It is not day."

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: You will go far, I fear.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: "Such mortal drugs I have but Mantua's law Is death to any he that utters them." Then him. Then me.

Speaker: webster
Dialogue: My lord!

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Shakespeare!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You are on my ground.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: By God, I'll fight the lot of you

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I am more than enough.

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: Will

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: I rejoiced at his death because I thought it was yours. That is all I know of Marlowe.

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: It's true, Will--it was a tavern brawlMarlowe attacked, and got his own knife in the eye. A quarrel about the bill

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: The bill! Oh, vanity, vanity!

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: Not the billing, the bill!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Oh God, I am free of it!

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Close it!

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: My Lord Wessex!

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Close it! Take it down stone by stone! I want it ploughed into the ground, and sown with quick lime!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Mr. Tilney, what is this?

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: Sedition and indecency!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: What?!

Speaker: webster
Dialogue: Master of the Revels, sir, over here, sir.

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: Where, boy?

Speaker: webster
Dialogue: I saw her bubbies!

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: A woman on the stage? A woman?

Speaker: webster
Dialogue: I swear it!

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: So, Henslowe! I say this theatre is closed! On the authority of the powers invested in my by the court--I close this theatre!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Why so?

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: For lewdness and unshamefacedness! For displaying a female on the public stage!

Speaker: webster
Dialogue: her.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: He's a woman!

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: That's who I meant! This theatre is closed! Notice will be posted!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Ned, I swear I knew nothing of this!

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Nobody knew!

Speaker: webster
Dialogue: He did! I saw him kissing her bubbies!

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: Closed! Closed, mark you, Henslowe!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: It is over.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: I am so sorry, Mr. Henslowe. I wanted to be an actor.  I am sorry, Will.

Speaker: wabash
Dialogue: Y-y-y-you w-w-w-were w-w-w-w- wonderful.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Everything all right?

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: I would have been goodI would have been great.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: So would I. We both would.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Lambert!

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: Well, Burbage--you never did know when your scene was over.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: That can wait. The Master of the Revels despises us for vagrants, tinkers, and peddlers of bombast. But my father, James Burbage, had the first licence to make a company of players from Her Majesty, and he drew from poets the literature of the age. Their fame will be our fame. So let them all know, we are men of parts. We are a brotherhood, and we will be a profession. Will Shakespeare has a play. I have a theatre. The Curtain is yours.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Will!

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: My ship is moored at Bankside, bound for Virginia on the afternoon tide--please do not weep, Lady De Lesseps, you are gaining a colony.

Speaker: de lesseps
Dialogue: And you are gaining five thousand pounds, my lordby these drafts in my hand.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Would you oblige me with fifty or so in gold?--just to settle my accounts at the dockside?

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Good morning, my lord. I see you are open for business so let's to church.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: My lord!

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: I will.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: God bless you!

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Thank you. Let go, there's a good nurse.

Speaker: makepeace
Dialogue: Licentiousness is made a show, vice is made a show, vanity and pride likewise made a show! This is the very business of show

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: Is this all right?

Speaker: wabash
Dialogue: T-t-t-two h-h-households b-both alike in d-d-d-dignity.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: We are lost.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: No, it will turn out well.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: How will it?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: I don't know, it's a mystery.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Wonderful!

Speaker: wabash
Dialogue: W-w-w-was it g-g-g-good?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Master Shakespeare

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Sam?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: It is not my fault, Master Shakespeare. I could do it yesterday.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Sam! Do me a speech, do me a line.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: "Parting is such sweet sorrow"

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Another little problem.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: What do we do now?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: The show must  you know

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Go on.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Juliet does not come on for twenty pages. It will be all right.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: How will it?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: I don't know. It's a mystery.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Can we talk?

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: No Juliet?!

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: No Juliet?!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: it will be all right, madam.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: What happened to Sam?

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Thomas Kent!

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: Do you know it?

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Every word.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: We will all be put in the clink.

Speaker: henslowe
Dialogue: See you in jail.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: "Such mortal drugs I have but Mantua's Law Is death to any he that utters them." Then him. Then me.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I am fortune's fool.

Speaker: fennyman
Dialogue: I was good. I was great.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Dead!

Speaker: the prince
Dialogue: "For never was a story of more woe Than this of Juliet and her Romeo."

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: I arrest you in the name of Queen Elizabeth!

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: Arrest who, Mr. Tilney?

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: Everybody! The Admiral's Men, The Chamberlain's Men and everyone of you ne'er-do-wells who stands in contempt of the authority invested in me by her Majesty.

Speaker: burbage
Dialogue: Contempt? You closed the Rose--I have not opened it.

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: That woman is a woman!

Speaker: alleyn
Dialogue: What?! A woman?! You mean that goat?!

Speaker: tilney
Dialogue: I'll see you all in the clink! In the same of her Majesty Queen Elizabeth

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Mr. Tilney!

Speaker: queen
Dialogue: Have a care with my name, you will wear it out.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: He is, Ma'am.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Your Majesty

Speaker: queen
Dialogue: There was a wager, I rememberas to whether a play can show the very truth and nature of love. I think you lost it today.  You are an eager boy. Did you like the play?

Speaker: webster
Dialogue: I liked it when she stabbed herself, your Majesty.

Speaker: queen
Dialogue: Master Shakespeare. Next time to you come to Greenwich, Come as yourself and we will speak some more. WILL bows deeply. The QUEEN turns to leave. The waves part for her.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Your Majesty!

Speaker: queen
Dialogue: Why, Lord Wessex! Lost your wife so soon?

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Indeed I am a bride short. How is this to end?

Speaker: queen
Dialogue: As stories must when love's denied--with tears and a journey. Those whom God has joined in marriage, not even I can put asunder.

Speaker: wessex
Dialogue: Fifty shillings.  Pounds.

Speaker: queen
Dialogue: Give it to Master Kent. He will see it rightfully home. WESSEX gives his purse to VIOLA.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: My Lady Wessex?

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: A hired player no longer. Fifty pounds, Will, for the poet of true love.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I am done with theatre. The playhouse is for dreamers. Look where the dream has brought us.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: It was we ourselves did that. And for my life to come I would not have it otherwise.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I have hurt you and I am sorry for it.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: If my hurt is to be that you will write no more, then I shall be the sorrier.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: A comedy! What will my hero be but the saddest wretch in the kingdom, sick with love?

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: An excellent beginning  Let him bea duke. And your heroine?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Sold in marriage and half way to America.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: At sea, then--a voyage to a new world?she lands upon a vast and empty shore. She is brought to the dukeOrsino.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Orsinogood name

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: But fearful of her virtue, she comes to him dressed as a boy

Speaker: will
Dialogue: and thus unable to declare her love

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: But all ends well.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: How does it?

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: I don't know. It's a mystery

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Nor you for me.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Good bye, my love, a thousand times good bye.

Speaker: viola
Dialogue: Write me well.
